title: The Big Bang Theory risks tarnishing its legacy with spin-offs
text:
Don’t follow Joey’s lead, The Big Bang Theory (Picture: Warner Bros./CBS)

The Big Bang Theory came to an end earlier this year after more than a decade, but with possible sequels on the horizon bosses need to learn from Friends to avoid ruining the show’s legacy.

We’ve made no secret of how much we love The Big Bang Theory – so when director Mark Cendrowski offered a glimmer of hope for a spin-off beyond Young Sheldon, it’s certainly got us excited for the possibility of revisiting the gang in the future.

After 12 years on air, there’s certainly appetite for more, even if the team – including creator Chuck Lorre – want to wait for just the right idea to make any possible continuation really worth it. And that’s the absolute best strategy.

When Friends ended in May 2004 it felt like the end of an era, but just four months later Matt LeBlanc was already back on our screens with Joey, which was almost unanimously summed up as everything wrong with a sitcom sequel. The Big Bang Theory needs to learn from its errors if we’re ever going to revisit the likes of Sheldon (played by Jim Parsons), Leonard (Johnny Galecki) and Penny (Kaley Cuoco).

Joey was axed midway through its second run and while there might have been unreasonable expectations after it followed on from an absolute ratings juggernaut – which is still regarded as almost the gold standard for sitcoms – it just didn’t hit the mark.

Kevin S. Bright – who was a direct and executive producer on both – has admitted in the past that the spin-off just didn’t have the same tone as its predecessor, and while Friends portrayed Joey Tribbiani as a lovable, carefree goof, that all changed when the follow up saw him move to Hollywood and try to grow up.

Joey was a bitter pill to swallow for Friends fans (Picture: NBC)

There was also an issue with how the character transformed from a real ladies’ man – literally one of his key defining characteristics – into someone without many friends, and also lacking in the skills to even really land a date. That doesn’t sound like the Joey we knew and loved, and it’s that kind of disregard for what’s come before that The Big Bang Theory team need to avoid if any potential spin-offs can even hope to retain some goodwill from a passionate fanbase.

Imagine a Sheldon sequel – which is unlikely considering Jim Parsons doesn’t seem keen on a reprise – where the character suddenly exudes charm, where he’s a real ladies man and where he’s an expect in the nuances of societal etiquette.

Or where Penny’s quirks give way to a book smart character struggling to land a man.

It just doesn’t sound right, and it’s these Joey traps The Big Bang Theory crew would have to avoid.

There also needs to be a reason for the next story being told, and that’s where the Friends team may have also let LeBlanc’s show down by rushing out the sequel less than half a year after its predecessor went off the air.

Sure, there’s something to be said for striking when the iron is hot, but look at how seemingly everyone online is clamouring for a Friends reunion or one-off comeback. Absence makes the heart grow fonder, while hot shotting out a cash-in can leave a bad taste for even the most passionate of fanbases.

So, TBBT bosses have got to take their time, let fans really miss having these characters around, and let the feeling of nostalgia grow as we start to wonder what happened to them after we last checked in.

Leonard and Penny were firm favourites for a spin-off with Big Bang Theory fans (Photo by Michael Yarish/CBS via Getty Images)

Then, it’s down to them to figure out where their stories have gone – making sure they actually fit into what was established over a decade of television – and then see how they can turn it into something that seems natural and worthwhile rather than forced and unnecessary.

Advertisement

Big Bang Theory has emulated Friends in many ways by becoming a true modern day classic sitcom which will almost definitely stand the test of time. Now, if there is any hope for a reprise in the future, it needs to learn one more lesson from the past and make sure we’re not still talking about a doomed Raj (Kunal Nayyar) spin-off in 15 years’ time.

The Big Bang Theory is available to stream on Netflix.
